Youth Radios investigation has uncovered another crucial part of the online sex trafficking infrastructure.
Girls describe photo studios in Oakland where young women pose in sets that look like bedrooms.
Studios provide lingerie, wigs and makeup.

Wikipedia is making its way into the classrooms of some top universities across the country.
The foundation behind the online encyclopedia is getting students from schools, including Harvard and Princeton, to write and edit articles.
But as NPR's Sarah Gonzalez reports, the effort is not expected to give the site more credibility in the academic world.
Any college student will tell you Wikipedia isn't a source you want to cite in a college paper.
Oh, no, definitely not.
Mr.
AJ BETTS(ph) (Student, Georgetown University): That's just a terrible idea.
You would get an F, I think, right away on the paper.
It has to be, like, a scholarly source.
It has to be something, like, legitimate.
Claire Carluccio, AJ Betts, Stefano Daniele and Ianthe Metzger are students at Georgetown University.
They say Wikipedia is unreliable because anyone can write articles, and the information is always changing.
Rodney Dunican is with the Wikimedia Foundation, which operates Wikipedia.
He knows reliability is a problem, but he says the project isn't meant to fix that.
(Wikimedia Foundation): I would say it's not so much the goal of making it accurate.
It's the goal of how we can increase and improve the articles in the public policy area.
Dunican says Wikipedia doesn't have enough public policy articles, so it's asking the nation's top public policy programs to help them write more.
The idea is for students to turn their course research into Wikipedia articles.
Nine universities are participating in it this fall.
At the beginning of the article, you have, like, a brief summary of everything that's there.
Ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding, ding.
That's the answer I've been looking for, thank you.
Rochelle Davis is a professor at Georgetown University.
Her class, Theorizing Culture and Politics, is kicking off the project by deconstructing a Wikipedia article.
Most students, like Adrian Bien, are noticing organizational problems.
You can literally get just so drowned in information, and then you just start clicking all these different links, and then you're like, oh, wait.
I'm reading about, like, zebras.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Davis says students are supposed to be looking out for things like misleading statements or missing information.
Because they're not experts, they couldn't point out that there were errors.
And there are errors in Wikipedia.
That's why Davis says she still won't allow her students to cite it.
It is not a scholarly article.
It is not even a credible thing.
It's a starting-off point.
And that's what Wikipedia claims to be: a starting-off point.
The purpose of the project isn't to make it a citable source.
Paul Courant is a librarian and professor of information at the University of Michigan.
He says library scientists will learn from the experiment, anyway.
If the entries don't improve, that tells us that the crowd-sourcing model is really extremely powerful.
For Professor Davis, the project is about students making complex information accessible to ordinary people.
She says that's what public policy is all about.
For them to be actually producing something that isn't just for me, but for them to actually go out in the world with what they have just researched I think is really exciting.
Fifteen weeks.
Just in the, let's say 48 or 72 hours from when I actually changed it, wrote my paper, people had already made changes and comments on my suggestions.

The capping of the oil flow off the Gulf Coast may only be temporary.
Engineers are now trying to decide whether it's safe to keep the oil well closed, or if they need to open it up and try once again to capture the oil.
In any event, the star of the show is a plucky, little piece of equipment called a 3-ram stack.
It sits on top of the well.
We've asked NPR's Richard Harris to answer a few of our lingering questions about this heroic piece of equipment.
Richard, I'm glad you're here once again, to help us understand this.
Sure.
And first, remind us again, what exactly this thing is doing.
Well, the 3-ram stack is part of what BP calls a sealing cap, which as the name suggests is sealing the top of the well.
And basicall, the rams are valves that can slam shut in the case of an emergency.
And when they closed the valves yesterday, the oil stopped flowing into the Gulf.
That's why it's sort of heroic.
